awd_abstract_narration:
1452800
PI: Pennell, Kelly

CAREER: Vapor Intrusion, Knowledge Brokers and Environmental Health - A Three-Dimensional Perspective

The average person spends 90 % of their time indoors, which makes indoor air quality extremely important. There are many sources of indoor air contamination, but one that is too often overlooked is the transport of subsurface vapors into indoor air spaces (i.e. vapor intrusion).Vapor intrusion is notoriously difficult to characterize because extremely low chemical concentrations in indoor air are health-relevant and modeling indoor air and subsurface environments requires sophisticated approaches. This project will bridge the gap that exists between air transport modeling of above ground spaces and subsurface spaces. The research introduces a novel approach, where for the first time a volatile organic chemical vapor intrusion model will incorporate atmospheric, indoor and subsurface environments, in an effort to address unexplained preliminary field data collected by the PI, as well as some recent reports of unexplained field observations in the literature. Since vapor intrusion regulations are rapidly emerging, new knowledge generated must be translated by scientists and engineers to engage with key stakeholders, quickly and effectively. The educational goal of this proposal is to train students as knowledge brokers to build bridges between academic researchers and key stakeholders, such as regulators, professionals, legislators, and community members. 

The modeling will involve computational fluid dynamic approaches. The field data sets include variations in indoor air concentrations and soil gas concentrations that are inconsistent with existing numerical models. Qualitatively, the field data does not mimic the current conceptual understanding of vapor intrusion, which makes current vapor intrusion models extremely limited in their ability to describe field observations. The proposed model will advance the field of environmental engineering by establishing important, and previously omitted connections between the subsurface and aboveground domains that are relevant for environmental fate and transport. Moreover, vapor intrusion characterization also requires scientific knowledge from many different disciplines (e.g. soil scientists, industrial hygienists, analytical chemists, environmental engineers) to fully understand the matter. This project will develop a new vapor intrusion modeling technique that combines subsurface fate and transport modeling with mechanical and industrial engineering approaches for modeling aboveground air transport. Research results will be integrated into vapor intrusion assessment practices, so that exposure risks are assessed using accurate science-based methods. The results of the research will be shared with relevant stakeholders to ensure research results gain relevancy for policy decisions.

por.por_cntn:
Indoor air pollution is extremely important in terms of a person’s overall health. There are many sources of indoor air pollution, but one that is too often overlooked is the transport of subsurface vapors into indoor air spaces (i.e. vapor intrusion). Volatile organic compound (VOC) vapor intrusion occurs due to VOC vapors migrating from subsurface contaminant sources into the overlying buildings. This type of vapor intrusion received increasing scientific and regulatory attention over the last three decades. VOC vapor transport depends on various factors such as the subsurface conditions, building characteristics, source characteristics, and general site conditions. Several numerical models have been developed to investigate vapor intrusion and the resulting VOC concentration in indoor spaces. However, vapor intrusion models previously used for hazardous waste site assessments lack the theoretical and conceptual framework to describe several field observations. For instance, vapor intrusion modeling approaches that predict transport of VOCs from subsurface locations into indoor spaces typically ignore the physics of airflow around a building, which induces pressure fields and building ventilation.  In addition, the role of VOC intrusion from subsurface piping systems had not been incorporated into previous vapor intrusion models. 

Intellectual merit: This research advances vapor intrusion science by accounting for aboveground, as well as subsurface transport processes.  We developed fate and transport models to describe chemical species transport between subsurface and indoor domains as a function of weather, building operation, sewer systems, and subsurface processes. We also investigated field data sets near hazardous waste sites and discovered VOCs from the polluted sites are transported via sewer networks and can migrate into indoor spaces. Together, the combined discoveries of this project allow new perspectives to inform the vapor intrusion community (e.g., researchers, regulators, consultants, and community groups) and offer new opportunities to mitigate inhalation exposures at vapor intrusion sites.

Broader Impacts: The educational plan included activities in which the research team engaged with decision makers to broker knowledge and foster informed decision-making using science from varied disciplines. The PI and her students engaged as knowledge brokers with policy makers, community members, and practitioners. They participated in workshops, formal and informal sharing opportunities, and partnered on field studies. These activities allowed for multidirectional perspectives to be translated into decisions and regulatory guidance. Through the offering and development of a new 500-level course, Environmental Health and Engineering, the PI trained 80 engineering students as knowledge brokers by teaching students skills to interpret scientific knowledge for relevant stakeholders so they can assist in fostering informed decisions about complex environmental challenges amidst the reality of uncertainty and incomplete knowledge. 

Research findings from this project have been published in several peer-reviewed journals and presented at national and international conferences. Over 10 undergraduate and graduate (both in MS and PhD levels) students were engaged in research experiences associated this project.
